column4: hi everybody, i have the latest version of 64bit ubuntu installed on my system. i have also installed the latest virtualbox package (3.2.4) but i'm unable to run a 64bit OS inside the virtualbox. any thoughts on this
You probably don't have hardware vitualization support, a quick way to check is by running "kmv-ok"
Sorry, "kvm-ok"
it doesn't support it, f**k
so, there's no way i can do this without getting a new system that supports hardware virtualization?
You can use "qemu-system-x86_64" for a 64 bit virtual machine, but it will be very slow.
binaryme: thanks for the info; hate intel, i've seen alot of amd system's that supoort virtualization
Actually, check your BIOS settings before giving up entirely.
i checked the info about virtualization long time ago regarding my system and it doesn't support it
Did you copy the entire partition rather than individual files? If so then you'll need to modify the UUID since it's no longer Unique :)
i copied the entire partition using gparted. how do i modify the UUID?
sudo tune2fs -U random /dev/sdXX but be warned that you will need to update all references to this UUID after you change it.
To update your fstab run "gksudo gedit /etc/fstab" and replace the old UUID with the new one (which you can find with "sudo blkid"
To update grub just run "sudo update-grub"
i run this on the usb version or the laptop's version?
USB
what do u mean by all references? i only have one partition on the usb
I mean configuration files that use that UUID to try to find the proper partition.
You're welcome.

hey, just a quick question, you had instructed me a little while back to change my UUID on the flash drive doing the following: sudo tune2fs -U random /dev/sdXX, updating fstab with the new UUID and running "grub update". is this all i have to do?
Yes.
thanks, i ljust wanted to make sure i wasn't missing anything else
You're welcome.
